column4: can someone explain to me why there are no dictionaries for OpenOffice.org ?
-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 786 2006-07-10 14:12 /usr/lib/openoffice/share/wordbook/en-US/soffice.dic
that is the only dictionary showing up, it is empty
I've been trying to get a spellchecker in OO.o for days, I've installed every package I can think of, but there simply aren't any dictionaries
I believe it uses myspell
it doesn't, though.  it is using that file I just pasted
which myspell dictionaries did you install?
okay I just went and installed every myspell package I could find.  most were already installed, some were not
will restart and see if it makes a difference
just restart openoffice
that's what I meant.  done.  no difference.  when I go to spell check, it immediately says "completed, do you want to restart at the top of the document ?", I click "yes", it closes the window
make sure tools > options > language has a language selected with an "abc" checkmark next to it
no mispellings are underlined in red
well the "Language Settings" appears now.  it was not there when I went to Tools > Options yesterday.  hopefully I can turn on a spellchecker now
the only one that shows up in the top is "OO.o Hunspell SpellChecker"
as well as a thesaurus
yes, that is what I have as well

restarted, still not working.  the drop-down for "Edit" on the dictionary shows English for Australia, Great Britain and USA.  I want the UK English, but any time I select it and close the window, it reverts to Australia English .. and none of it produces any spell checking
what is selected in tools > options > language settings > language > default languages for documents > western?
English (Canada)
set that to what you desire, make sure it has the "abc" checkmark next to it
okay done: <ABC> English (UK)
still no spellchecking being done
I restarted OO.o
k, make sure the dictionary is using uk as well
it reset the document one to English (Canada) now
hmm, that won't do
the edit button shows "English (Australia)" and if I change it, it always reverts to that
I tried "English (Australia)" in the default document one, and that stuck ... but I would prefer "English (UK)" dictionaries.  it is spellchecking now
I did install the myspell dicts for English GB, US and AU
try starting with a blank document and changing the language to UK.  I just changed mine to canada and had to restart OO to get it to go back to USA (my default)
it seems to think the only dictionary in existance is "English (Australia)"
is there an <abc> next to the western language selection of English (UK)?
myspell-en-gb is already the newest version. myspell-en-au is already the newest version. myspell-en-us is already the newest version.
yes, there is an ABC
but if I select "ABC - English (UK)" it immediately reverts to the "English (Canada)" or "ABC - English (Australia)", whichever I had last selected
thank you kindly for your help, by the way.  this has been an issue since I switched to Ubuntu
and "English (Australia)" is a far better dictionary for me than ""
I see what you mean, I change mine to UK, restart OO and it shows up as USA again.  There must be something we are missing...
hm
perhaps the package that has the English UK dictionary is broken ?
I can't even make the default language for my documents stay as UK
english Australia and USA work here, I just tried both
oh I missed it, do you notice the checkbox that says "For the current document only", is taht grayed out for you as well in default doc lang settings?
yes, it is grayed out

I have to go now, but here are my thoughts: the ubuntu build my grab the language from elsewhere (locale settings?), you may be able to do this: http://www.oooforum.org/forum/viewtopic.phtml?p=157058  good luck
thank you very much for your help
take a look at equivs, but be sure that it is not actually a broken package...
I saw mention of equivs on a Debian forum, but I didn't see it on this system.  is it available on Ubuntu then ?
by the way, I'm assuming this isn't an official package
if so, I will uninstall the apps it thinks are broken and install 'equivs'
no, what exactly is broken?

I am trying to use an older version of the Opera web browser (which depends on a no-longer-existant, empty, transitional package) and a very new version of TuxPaint (which asks for *very* specific versions of common libs that it doesn't actually need)
you just use equivs to make a fake package with the name of that dep but doesn't actually install anything
well that is exactly what I need.  I was just asking if Ubuntu had this package ... as I can't install anything until apt removes these packages it thinks are broken
yes, it does.  It is in universe
thanks.  will investigate equivs now
the 8.04 CDs have a serious security issue
what's the link to the bug you are referring to?
well blah.  8.04.1 and 8.10 have a seriously broken Intel driver
there are numerous bug reports about it, so I'm not sure which is the main/official one.  here's an example: https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+bug/252094
what was the security issue in 8.04, and wouldn't it just be fixed by an apt-get upgrade ?
that bug just shows people claiming degraded performance in intrepid.  In any case, you can just install 8.04 and try to downgrade to whatever package you feel 8.04 had that was better
8.04.1 is 8.04 with upgrades, so if you claim 8.04.1 has the issue, the upgrade would give you the same issue
this is on a new laptop I bought for my father.  I have never tried 8.04 on this laptop, only got it yesterday and installed 8.10 on it.  the Intel drivers that come with 8.10 are totally buggy
if compiz is on, then all other GL apps produce incorrect layering and tons of glitches.  if compiz is off, then certain glitches remain
you claimed 8.04.1 had these bugs.  Why not try 8.04.1?
I tried some of the suggested xorg.conf changes, and while they removed the glitching, they end up crashing Xorg and it won't reload until a reboot
I would rather than 8.10 working, as I've already spent many hours configuring things on this system, will be a pain to reinstall, only to find it's the same
best to just ask for help with that directly then
do you know anything about Intel drivers on laptops ?  I have one work laptop running 8.something with no issues.  other than that, I've never used Intel
sorry, I have a laptop with one but it "just works" so I don't know anything about it
or earlier
on the same laptop ?
yes
out of curiousity, which chipset ?  (lspci|grep -i vga)
laptops off right now
if you read the source code though, you'll see it is not the same
3.x is not the default version of python in any ubuntu version
okay, 2.6.1 apparently, but there are only modules for 2.4 and 2.5
modules for what?
I'm on an older Ubuntu version (8.10 if I recall) and some recentish updates have broken a number of Python apps.  in this case python-wxversion only has 2.4 and 2.5 modules, but not one for 2.6
seems strange (from memory) that default python is 2.6 there, but in any case 8.10 is eol

I'll be updating to 10.04 soon, via clean install.  I am aware that it's old, I'm just wondering how one goes about setting the default python version ?  or should I just us mv on the files in /usr/bin ?

you shouldn't change the default python version.  Many scripts that are used by the operating system need the default python version to be what it is and stuff will likely break.  If you need to have some particular script run with 2.5, just use env python2.5 (python2.5 should be in the repositories)

well, the point is kind of that some apps broke as the result of 2.6 being installed or set to default.  I've run into this problem twice now, where modules don't exist for 2.6, so I wanted to fix future occurances as well
are you positive that python2.6 was not always the default.  I really doubt that would change in an update

all I know is that an app I've been using for years no longer loads (because it needs 2.4 or 2.5, not 2.6) and that my own app I was creating with PyGame also wouldn't work on 2.6, as there are again modules only for 2.4 and 2.5
see if you can replicate this behavior on a supported version. You mentioned wx but it certainly works with 2.6

as I said, I'm on 8.10, and some update within the last month or so caused it to switch to a default of 2.6 Python, which has broke many apps.  I'll go poke at it manually until I upgrade to 10.04, thanks.

as I said, I really doubt an update would change the default python version.  I can't obtain too much info about intrepid however as I don't have an intrepid install and the online tools drop unsupported versions
if you have a broken system already and don't really care if it breaks more I guess you can mess with /usr/share/python/debian_defaults ... (caveat emptor)
I'll probably just edit the broken app to use 2.5, seems safest after you've scared me about changing the system default
I would just install 10.04 and be done with it

not that simple, unfortunately.  this system is an NFS server to other computers in the house, and it's also an Internet server, and it's also a multiseat desktop.  so downtime ruins a lot of people's days.  :p
I'll probably do the update this weekend at 2:AM or something so nobody's using any of it
